Posts.Title: HELP! 10 year old with bc cjsocal Mary-Lou

Posts.Content: Apr 5, 2009 10:40PM SandyL wrote: Binney, I'm so glad you posted and explained breast lymphedema so clearly and thoroughly.  Kritzy, I second Binney's recommendation to find a different lymphedema therapist and get another opinion. Binney, I'm also glad you mentioned the itching could possibly indicate cellulitis.  I wondered if that's what it could be, but was hesitant to say since I wasn't sure.   Kritzy, I think my radiation oncologist and the technicians should have considered canceling my last three or four treatments. I wish I'd spoken up, because I think at that point my skin became damaged beyond repair.  My neck even has some permanent damage.  I can't wear necklaces any more; the chains chafe the skin and really bother me.  Some collars are the same way.  In my previous post I mentioned seeing my radiation oncologist when I started having pain about a year after having radiation.  I actually saw a different oncologist as mine had left the practice.  He was horrified when he saw how much damage I had.  I wonder if he would have done things differently or at least stopped the treatments sooner.  Oh well, what's done is done. Again, good luck! Sandy
Posts.Title: Itchy breast (18 month post treatment) kritzy bluewillow

Posts.Content: Apr 5, 2009 09:51AM SandyL wrote: kritzy, I had radiation after having my second mastectomy and chemo.  Like you, I also had some pretty significant skin damage, only some of which healed completely.  About a year after rads, I started having some discomfort in the radiated area.  Also like you, I managed to work myself into a frenzy thinking it was mets or a recurrence.  I had talked myself into believing it was bone mets in my ribs when I saw my radiation oncologist, who said it was not abnormal to have continuing effects from the radiation even after a year or longer.  He recommended a bone scan just to be sure, but it was negative for mets and the pain eventually faded away. In your case, I wonder if your edema is actually lymphedema of your breast?  I have lymphedema in my left arm, hand, and fingers.  I'm not as familiar with lymphedema of the breast, but I know there are several women who have it who post on the lymphedema forum.  You may want to consider doing some research on it and post there as well.  Lymphedema is a nuisance, but it's better than a recurrence of your cancer.  Glad your rads onc was able to put your mind at ease.  Good luck! Sandy

Posts.Content: Aug 28, 2008 01:27AM SandyL wrote: Shari, Before I developed lymphedema in my left arm, hand, and fingers about five years ago, my arm ached like yours for several months.  I tried to keep it elevated as much as possible, but there were times I could barely type due to the discomfort.  Then one day the aching stopped and the swelling began.  After that I had some periods where it would ache, but it wasn't nearly as bad as it had been before my arm swelled.  I've read where other women have similar aching, so I think it's normal. Good luck! Sandy
Posts.Title: Arm Pain SheriH sccruiser

Posts.Content: Apr 25, 2009 01:20PM - edited Apr 25, 2009 01:20PM by SandyL veto, I'm so sorry that you have to deal with this and that you aren't getting clear information from your doctors.  I've had two excisional biopsies (both positive for cancer), so I don't know much about the other types.  However, I do know you have to have a suspicious area or lump for any type of biopsy.  I think you need more answers and information before you can make a decision about how to proceed.  Here are the questions I would ask. First, what was on the mammogram that suggests possible IBC?  Second, if the surgeon you saw said you didn't have a lump or mass, why did he change his mind and decide to do a biopsy? I would ask him exactly what he plans to biopsy.  I would surely think he would want you to have a mammogram on your other breast before proceeding.  I would also think he would have an ultrasound done first, although I should add that I don't know much about IBC.  I do know it's usually very aggressive and harder to diagnose, but you should still have time to get some straight answers and feel more comfortable that you're proceeding in the right direction.  I would schedule another appointment and get more information and also ask if you should have another round of antibiotics to rule out mastitis first.  If the surgeon isn't willing to answer your questions, but insists on proceeding even though you're uncertain, then I suggest you find a different surgeon who will explain everything to your satisfaction.  Even though we tend to look up to doctors and surgeons, remember they are working for you and either you or your insurance company is paying them.  You shouldn't be forced to make important decisions like this when you're scared and still have questions. By the way, my first biopsy was in 1986 and I had regular anesthetic, but the second was in 2002 and I had twilight sleep anesthetic, which meant I wasn't put under as deep.  I could hear the music in the operating room and also hear part of the conversation, although I couldn't feel anything.  It was much easier to deal with and recover from.    My condolences on the loss of your husband.  I don't know how helpful I've been, but I wish you good luck as you deal with this and I hope it turns out just to be mastitis and not IBC. Good luck!  Sandy
Posts.Title: Punch or Incisional? veto ibcspouse

Posts.Content: Feb 24, 2009 01:11PM SandyL wrote: kgoodfl, Good luck with your surgery tomorrow.  I can't identify with what you're going through; I've had bc twice, but both times I felt the lumps first and subsequent biopsies determined they were malignant. My SIL has had several biopsies; they all turned out to be benign.  But they always check; they don't want to miss breast cancer just because all her previous tumors were okay.  I hope yours is simply scar tissue or benign and you don't have to join our ranks.   Regarding your kids, honestly I think I'd be as honest as possible with them.  Since they already suspect something is wrong, they're going to worry no matter what you say.  Perhaps you can tell them you have a lump in your breast that has to be checked, that it's probably nothing but the doctors want to double-check to be sure, and you'll be home a few hours after the surgery.  If you can stay upbeat with them it will help alleviate their concern.  Try not to worry too much (yeah, right!) and try to get some sleep tonight.   Good luck! Sandy
Posts.Title: had core now lump is back excision next floridian SandyL

Posts.Content: May 12, 2009 11:27AM SandyL wrote: I agree that the 7-10 days is a positive sign, but... I think it's cruel to make you wait, even if the results are good.  I would call either your primary or your gyn's office and explain that you're very anxious about the results and you'd like to know NOW. I would certainly think one of your doctors could take enough time to review the results with you over the phone.  If they don't want to discuss the results on the phone, then insist on an immediate appointment.
Posts.Title: Would a Doctor Make Me Wait? Magawisca jpann39

Posts.Content: May 14, 2009 08:36AM SandyL wrote: Maga ~ I'm so happy you received good news!  Now you can relax and wait for the details without worrying.   Jule ~ I hope your scans are clear and you can relax, too.  I'll watch for good news from you.  I used to be a complete basket case in the week(s) before my checkups.  (I've had bc twice, the first time in 1986 and the second in 2002.  The second was a new primary rather than a recurrence.).  It was especially difficult before the checkups following my first round of bc, probably because I was in my mid-30s and my kids were still young.  During the 50-minute drive to find out the results of my tests and scans, I would picture every possible scenario in which I'd be told my cancer had returned and spread.  I was always a complete wreck.  Then my onc or surgeon would tell me everything was clear and I would visibly relax and I'd be fine...until the weeks before my next checkup.  As the years went by with no recurrence, I eventually managed to put cancer out of my mind.  It became part of my past and I could think about it without fear.   It was a blow to find the new lump in 2002, but in a lot of ways it was easier because so many years had gone by and I'd had the experience of the cancer not recurring after the first time.  In spite of having four positive nodes the second time as opposed to none the first time, I was able to hold onto the fact that I'd beat it the first time and it made me optimistic I could do it again.  I was still nervous when going for checkups, especially following scans, but I wasn't such a basket case as before.  One time though, my onc didn't tell me the results of the scans when he came in the exam room.  He talked about other things including blood test results, but I finally had to ask him how the scans came out.  He was embarrassed and apologized for not telling me sooner that they were fine.  I gently reminded him he should ALWAYS start with that news, then go onto the other things.   I don't worry about test results now because I don't go for checkups due to losing my health insurance along with my job about 2 1/2 years ago.  I know my cancer could still recur, but I simply can't afford the checkups and lab work, much less any scans.  Fortunately I don't have any symptoms of recurrence, so I'm keeping my fingers crossed that nothing comes up.   Good luck to both of you!
Posts.Title: Would a Doctor Make Me Wait? Magawisca jpann39
